newsitem.title: USA: Silicon Graphics buys ParaGraph, sets up 3-D unit.
newsitem.headline: Silicon Graphics buys ParaGraph, sets up 3-D unit.

text.p: Silicon Graphics Inc. said Wednesday it agreed to acquire ParaGraph International, a company that makes three-dimensional Internet software for personal computers.

Silicon Graphics also said it is establishing a new company, called Cosmo Software, to focus on the fast-emerging market for interactive 3-D Internet software, which runs on multiple computer systems.
ParaGraph will be integrated into the new Cosmo unit, which will spearhead Silicon Graphics' Second Web initiative to bring more engaging multimedia content and applications to the World Wide Web.
Financial terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.

Founded in 1989 by world chess champion Garry Kasparov, Stepan Pachikov and prominent Russian scientists, ParaGraph has become a leader in virtual reality and three-dimensional Web tools and software, as well as pen-based technologies.
Kasparov still holds an unspecified stake in ParaGraph, which is based in Campbell, Calif., with research and development activities both there and in Moscow.

Silicon Graphics, which has been struggling to put its financial house in order after a series of quarterly profit shortfalls and a sweeping but turbulent product transition, said the value of the deal was not financially material.
Dr. Kai-Fu Lee, named president of Cosmo Software, said Forrester Research estimates that by the year 2000 the market it is addressing will exceed $500 million in revenues.

Cosmo Software will combine the two companies' product lines, which include free 3-D browsers and revenue-generating products ranging from authoring tools for $39 to Cosmo server products that cost upward of $2,000.

Silicon Graphics has been active in the emerging business of creating three-dimensional environments on the Web and has bundled its Cosmo Player virtual reality browser with ParaGraph's Internet3D family of authoring tools.
The company intends to expand the partnership to make it possible for consumers to create their own 3-D worlds.
ParaGraph set out to help people build their own virtual worlds, including 3-D Web sites inhabited with digital personalities known as avatars.
Paragraph boasts an in-house team of 90 scientists, engineers and digital artists among a total of 140 employees, around 100 of whom are at its facilities in Russia.
Before the acquisition, ParaGraph projected its revenues will roughly double this year to $12 million.

The acquisition comes as the market for software capable of authoring and displaying 3-D multimedia graphics is heating up. Just one week ago, Microsoft Corp. snapped up Dimension X, a privately held San Francisco startup that provides 3D multimedia authoring software.
Industry sources said the estimated price tag on each of the two transactions was less than $50 million.
